newsitem.title: CHINA: PRESS DIGEST - Chinese newspapers - April 15.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Chinese newspapers - April 15.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Chinese political and business stories in leading newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Beijing. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not guarantee their accuracy. Telephone: (8610) 6532-1921. Fax: (8610) 6532-4978.
PEOPLE'S DAILY
- Newspaper hails new role model, Wang Qimin, the "New Iron Man", a leading scientist at the Daqing Oilfield
- A delegation of the Communist Party of China leaves for goodwill visit to Vietnam and Laos on Monday
- Authorities punished eight publishing houses engaged in illegal activities.
XINHUA DAILY TELEGRAPH
- Premier Li Peng tells visiting Prime Minister of Mauritius, Navin Ramgoolam, that China attaches great importance to relations with Mauritius.
- Chinese Defense Minister Chi Haotian and the visiting Russian counterpart Igor Rodionov agree to improve military ties
- Lu Ping, official in charge of Hong Kong and Macau affairs, says establishment of preliminary working committee is not necessary for return of Macau
ECONOMIC DAILY
- Daqing oil administration makes pre-tax profits of 18.78 billion yuan in 1996
- Economic and Trade Commission sets target of 96.3 percent for 1997 sales to production ratio for industrial firms
CHINA SECURITIES
- Zhang Haoruo, vice minister of state commission of economic restructuring, warns of potential financial risks in China
- Shanghai banks sell 4.525 billion yuan of record issue of 124 billion yuan of treasury bonds by April 11
FINANCIAL NEWS
- State Development Bank and Bank of Communications hold meeting to promote closer ties
- China creates 9,200 share holding companies by restructuring state firms by end-1996
ECONOMIC INFORMATION DAILY
- Ministry of Railways to crack down on additional charges
- Editorial discusses factors behind slow sales of China's record issue of 123 billion yuan of treasury bonds
BEIJING ECONOMIC DAILY
- Beijing city gross domestic product growth at 7.5 percent in first quarter, down by three percentage points from year-ago period
CHINA DAILY
- Exports rocket by more than 25 percent to hit $35.5 billion in first quarter of 1997 after a year of slackened performance
